title: How Bad Is My Hearing Loss?
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

content: If someone has ever asked you to repeat yourself at a crowded restaurant, but that person can hear you just fine during the quiet car ride home, you know that hearing loss can affect people in different ways.
There’s a wide spectrum that spans the distance between normal hearing and profound hearing loss, with many sounds that people may or may not be able to hear along the way.
Sounds are measured in units called decibels. The more sounds that you can’t hear at a certain decibel level, the greater your hearing loss is. The different degrees are broken down as follows:

content_blocks.text: If someone has ever asked you to repeat yourself at a crowded restaurant, but that person can hear you just fine during the quiet car ride home, you know that hearing loss can affect people in different ways.
There’s a wide spectrum that spans the distance between normal hearing and profound hearing loss, with many sounds that people may or may not be able to hear along the way.
Sounds are measured in units called decibels. The more sounds that you can’t hear at a certain decibel level, the greater your hearing loss is. The different degrees are broken down as follows:

sections.heading: Normal Hearing: No More Than 25 Decibels of Hearing Loss
content: Most adults have normal hearing. If you do, this means that you can hear the things that you’d expect to hear, like your friends talking to you, as well as quiet sounds, like someone whispering to you from a few feet away.
With normal hearing, you can hear these sounds, which people with any degree of hearing loss can’t hear:

content_blocks.text: Most adults have normal hearing. If you do, this means that you can hear the things that you’d expect to hear, like your friends talking to you, as well as quiet sounds, like someone whispering to you from a few feet away.
With normal hearing, you can hear these sounds, which people with any degree of hearing loss can’t hear:

sections.heading: Mild Hearing Loss: Between 26 and 40 Decibels
content: Some people who have mild hearing loss may not know that they have a problem. They can still hear most of what they heard when they had normal hearing, and they’re able to hear many sounds if they get closer to the source or raise the volume.
If you have mild hearing loss, you may not be able to hear:
bullets: Water babbling in a brook or stream

content_blocks.text: Some people who have mild hearing loss may not know that they have a problem. They can still hear most of what they heard when they had normal hearing, and they’re able to hear many sounds if they get closer to the source or raise the volume.
If you have mild hearing loss, you may not be able to hear:
associated_bullets: Water babbling in a brook or stream

sections.heading: Moderate Hearing Loss: Between 41 and 55 Decibels
content: At this level of hearing loss, you may miss out on some of the sounds that you’ve heard before. If you pay attention, you’ll only hear silence at times when you used to hear soft sounds.
If you have moderate hearing loss, you likely won’t be able to hear:
bullets: People working in a quiet office

content_blocks.text: At this level of hearing loss, you may miss out on some of the sounds that you’ve heard before. If you pay attention, you’ll only hear silence at times when you used to hear soft sounds.
If you have moderate hearing loss, you likely won’t be able to hear:
associated_bullets: People working in a quiet office

sections.heading: Moderate to Severe Hearing Loss: Between 56 and 70 Decibels
content: Some people with moderate to severe hearing loss have trouble hearing their friends and family, which can make it hard for them to feel like they’re a part of things at social events, which can be depressing.
If you have moderate to severe hearing loss, you typically won’t be able to hear:
bullets: People talking at a normal volume

content_blocks.text: Some people with moderate to severe hearing loss have trouble hearing their friends and family, which can make it hard for them to feel like they’re a part of things at social events, which can be depressing.
If you have moderate to severe hearing loss, you typically won’t be able to hear:
associated_bullets: People talking at a normal volume

associated_bullets: People talking at a normal volume

sections.heading: Severe Hearing Loss: Between 71 and 90 Decibels
content: Those with severe hearing loss miss out on the things in their lives that they would want to hear, like the laughter of their friends or grandkids. They’re likely to raise the volume on the TV to a level that will bother others in the room, just so that they can hear their shows.
If you have severe hearing loss, you probably won’t be able to hear:
bullets: The sound of a vacuum cleaner

content_blocks.text: Those with severe hearing loss miss out on the things in their lives that they would want to hear, like the laughter of their friends or grandkids. They’re likely to raise the volume on the TV to a level that will bother others in the room, just so that they can hear their shows.
If you have severe hearing loss, you probably won’t be able to hear:
associated_bullets: The sound of a vacuum cleaner

sections.heading: Profound Hearing Loss: Between 91 and 100 Decibels
content: People with this level of hearing loss spend most of their day in silence when the world around them is bursting with normal-volume sounds. They may still be able to hear extreme booms and other loud sounds, like thunder and fireworks.
If you have profound hearing loss, you probably won’t be able to hear:

content_blocks.text: People with this level of hearing loss spend most of their day in silence when the world around them is bursting with normal-volume sounds. They may still be able to hear extreme booms and other loud sounds, like thunder and fireworks.
If you have profound hearing loss, you probably won’t be able to hear:

sections.heading: How to Get Help
content: If you think that you have hearing loss, ask your doctor to check your hearing. You may need to see an ear- nose -throat doctor or a special hearing doctor called an audiologist to help with treatment if test results show that you do have hearing loss.
There are many options to help you hear more sounds in your world again and to prevent future hearing loss, such as:
bullets: Ear plugs to protect your hearing
Special services for people with hearing loss offered at theaters, ballgames and houses of worship
Cochlear implants (for severe and profound hearing loss or a poor ability to understand spoken words)

meta_description: Adults can have different degrees of hearing loss, from mild to profound. Learn which sounds people aren’t able to hear with different degrees of hearing loss.
